title: ECB plot £50m revolution for women's cricket in revamp that will see number of pros triple
text:
The ECB hopes to pump £50m into 'transforming the women's game' over the next five years, and will fund 40 new full-time professional domestic contracts.

England's thrashing by Australia in the women's Ashes this summer highlighted the huge disparity in the domestic setups, and this new strategy is intended to provide a bigger pool of players for the national team.

As part of the action plan, eight regions will be created, who will compete in a regional 20-over and 50-over competition that is intended to be 'best versus best'.

England captain Heather Knight, pictured, said she'd ‘love to be a 10-year-old girl again’

However, it means that as of next year fans will have to get used to these new regions at the same time as being introduced to the eight city-based Hundred franchises.

The ECB said that streamlining the structure of women's and girl's cricket is necessary to help eliminate the 'black pockets' and 'postcode lottery' that currently exist.

In performance terms, the number of professional contracts will almost treble with the new investment, from the 22 existing England Women Centrally Contracted players to 62.

Knight recalled being ‘sniggered’ at when she was 14 and said she wanted to be a pro cricketer

This will help bridge the gap with Australia, where around 130 players are either semi-professional or professional.

Yet the number of new contracts is considerably less than one proposal discussed with counties for there to be at least 120 semi-professional contracts.

Following a consultation process it was decided that offering fewer full-time contracts would better serve the national team as those players could push harder for England selection.

England captain Heather Knight said she would 'love to be a 10-year-old girl again' with this new pathway.

Speaking at the launch event in London, she recalled being 'sniggered' at when she said aged 14 that she wanted to be a professional cricketer and said she hoped the new strategy would reduce the drop-off in girls playing cricket.

Ellyse Perry of Australia bats as Amy Jones of England attempts to take a catch during a test

Over the next two years, £20million will be invested, with a total of £50m then invested over the next five years if the initial stage of the plan is successful.

Clare Connor, the former England captain and ECB's Managing Director of Women's Cricket, said the rate of change needed to be 'accelerated' and that there needed to be one unified pathway in order do achieve this.

'Recent initiatives have given women and girls more opportunities to play, such as All Stars Cricket for 5-8-year-olds, the South Asian female activators programme, and the Kia Super League for our most talented domestic cricketers,' she said.

'But to truly transform women's and girls' cricket, we must now move from targeted standalone programmes to addressing the whole pathway as one.'
description: As part of the action plan, eight new regions will be created, who will compete in a new regional T20 and ODI competition that is intended to be 'best versus best', feeding the England set up better than now.
